title: 1 Course Information
text:
This course provides a foundation in demographic analysis and programming using the R programming language. It introduces students to the fundamentals of data analysis and visualization in the context of population studies, emphasizing reproducible and transparent research practices. Topics covered include demographic principles (fertility, mortality, migration, and population composition), data sources (censuses, vital statistics, surveys, and international databases), and computational methods for analyzing and visualizing population trends using R.
Students will learn to work with major demographic datasets such as the World Population Prospects (WPP), Human Mortality Database (HMD), Human Fertility Database (HFD), and national sources like DEIS and IPUMS. Through hands-on labs, students will gain experience in importing, cleaning, transforming, and visualizing data, and in calculating standard demographic indicators including crude rates, age-specific rates, and total fertility rates.
Emphasis will be on producing clear, reproducible, and interpretable analyses using best practices in data science. Students will primarily complete individual programming assignments and applied demographic labs designed to build their technical and conceptual understanding. Assessment will include weekly labs, a midterm data quality project, and a final reproducible demographic analysis using Quarto. The course assumes no prior experience with R and is ideal preparation for advanced courses in applied demography, data analytics, and population research.



There are no prerequisites. Students are assumed to have zero prior programming experience for this course.

text:
1 PRC 999 / 9999Intro to Population Data ScienceSpring 2026





Department: Population Research Center @ PSU
Credits: 3
Description:
This course provides a foundation in demographic analysis and programming using the R programming language. It introduces students to the fundamentals of data analysis and visualization in the context of population studies, emphasizing reproducible and transparent research practices. Topics covered include demographic principles (fertility, mortality, migration, and population composition), data sources (censuses, vital statistics, surveys, and international databases), and computational methods for analyzing and visualizing population trends using R.
Students will learn to work with major demographic datasets such as the World Population Prospects (WPP), Human Mortality Database (HMD), Human Fertility Database (HFD), and national sources like DEIS and IPUMS. Through hands-on labs, students will gain experience in importing, cleaning, transforming, and visualizing data, and in calculating standard demographic indicators including crude rates, age-specific rates, and total fertility rates.
Emphasis will be on producing clear, reproducible, and interpretable analyses using best practices in data science. Students will primarily complete individual programming assignments and applied demographic labs designed to build their technical and conceptual understanding. Assessment will include weekly labs, a midterm data quality project, and a final reproducible demographic analysis using Quarto. The course assumes no prior experience with R and is ideal preparation for advanced courses in applied demography, data analytics, and population research.
Learning Objectives:
Having successfully completed this course, students will be able to:

Develop and implement demographic analyses using R by:

Employing modular and reproducible coding practices for population data analysis.
Writing well-documented R scripts and Quarto notebooks to conduct demographic computations.
Applying computational problem-solving skills to real demographic datasets (e.g., censuses, vital statistics, surveys).

Compute and interpret key demographic indicators, including:

Crude and age-specific fertility and mortality rates.
Total fertility rate (TFR), mean age at childbearing, and life expectancy.
Measures of population growth, dependency ratios, and age structure.

Work confidently with demographic data sources by:

Importing, cleaning, and validating data from major repositories (WPP, HMD, HFD, IPUMS, DEIS).
Assessing data quality, completeness, and comparability across sources.
Managing and transforming datasets using tidyverse tools.

Reproducibly visualize and communicate demographic patterns by:

Creating clear and informative graphics (e.g., population pyramids, Lexis diagrams, time trends).
Applying effective data visualization principles using ggplot2 and related packages.
Producing Quarto-based reports integrating code, text, and visual output.

Engage with emerging areas of digital and computational demography by:

Collecting data via web scraping and APIs.
Mapping demographic data using spatial analysis tools (sf, tmap).
Exploring microsimulation and kinship modeling approaches (socsim, kinship2).


Prerequisites:
There are no prerequisites. Students are assumed to have zero prior programming experience for this course.
